oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bi-Centennial Special Excursion Ticket
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1886 New York State Bi-Centennial. Knowersville to Albany. Good for period July 19-22, 1886.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Railroads; Transportation -- Tickets; Anniversaries; Transportation; Railroad stations; Travel; Altamont (N.Y.); Delaware and Hudson Railway Company
Tickets; Transportation; Railroads; Travel;
Delaware and Hudson Canal Company
Community & Events; Transportation; Business & Industry;
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Village of Altamont - Albany County - New York; Knowersville - Albany County - New York;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Ticket; col.; 1 3/4 x 3 in. (4.45 x 7.62 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Knowersville was the Village's original name before 1887 when Albany resident Lucie Rochefort Cassidy, wife of politician William Cassidy, used her friendship with US President Grover Cleveland to have the Village eventually renamed to Altamont, which means "high mountain".
Note: President Grover Cleveland came to Albany on Thursday, July 22, 1886 to take part in the NYS Bi-Centennial Celebration. He was a guest of Governor David B. Hill during his brief stay in Albany. Gov. Hill, (once Pres. Cleveland's NYS Lt. Governor) was inaugurated as Governor of NYS in January 1885.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational uses. Please cite as Village of Altamont Archives and Museum. Prior written permission is required for any other use of the images.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Delaware and Hudson Station (D&H) Cyanotype
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard showing passengers and dog in winter at D&H Station, Altamont, NY. The 35 mile long passenger service line built in the 1850's was originally known as the Albany & Susquehanna Railroad and ran from Albany to Schoharie Junction, NY. Thanks in part to Hiram Gram, Altamont's first mayor, the railroad company included a stop in Knowersville, which later became known as the Village of Altamont.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
